title: Print Checklist
publication_title: Manet Paintings and Works on Paper at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">fig. 1 After Diego Rodríguez de Velázquez (Spanish, 1599–1660)  
Published by Cadart et Chevalier Éditeurs (French, 1861–1863)  
Printed by Auguste Delâtre (French, 1822–1907)  
The Little Cavaliers  
1860, published 1862  
Etching, drypoint, roulette, and bitten tone in black on gray chine, laid down on ivory wove paper (chine collé); 240 × 380 mm (image); 248 × 391 mm (plate); 242 × 383 mm (primary support); 319 × 448 mm (secondary support)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Robert A. Waller Fund, 1950.1453  
Harris 5 III/V; Guérin 8 III/IV; Moreau-Nélaton 5 III/IV

fig. 2 After Diego Rodríguez de Velázquez (Spanish, 1599–1660)  
The Little Cavaliers  
1860, reworked 1867/74  
Etching, drypoint, roulette, and bitten tone in black on ivory Japanese paper, laid down on tan wove paper (chine collé); 240 × 382 mm (image); 250 × 390 mm (plate); 334 × 486 mm (primary support); 337 × 497 mm (secondary support)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Carter H. Harrison and Prints and Drawings Club Funds, 1955.1064  
Harris 5 V/V; Guérin 8 IV/IV; Moreau-Nélaton 5 IV/IV

</section><section id="figures"> fig. 1 Édouard Manet (French, 1832–1883) after Diego Rodríguez de Velázquez (Spanish, 1599–1660). Published by Cadart et Chevalier Éditeurs (French, 1861–1863). Printed by Auguste Delâtre (French, 1822–1907). The Little Cavaliers, 1860, published 1862. Etching, drypoint, roulette, and bitten tone in black on gray chine, laid down on ivory wove paper (chine collé); 240 × 380 mm (image); 248 × 391 mm (plate); 242 × 383 mm (primary support); 319 × 448 mm (secondary support). The Art Institute of Chicago, Robert A. Waller Fund, 1950.1453. Harris 5 III/V; Guérin 8 III/IV; Moreau-Nélaton 5 III/IV.

fig. 2 Édouard Manet (French, 1832–1883) after Diego Rodríguez de Velázquez (Spanish, 1599–1660). The Little Cavaliers, 1860, reworked 1867/74. Etching, drypoint, roulette, and bitten tone in black on ivory Japanese paper, laid down on tan wove paper (chine collé); 240 × 382 mm (image); 250 × 390 mm (plate); 334 × 486 mm (primary support); 337 × 497 mm (secondary support). The Art Institute of Chicago, Carter H. Harrison and Prints and Drawings Club Funds, 1955.1064. Harris 5 V/V; Guérin 8 IV/IV; Moreau-Nélaton 5 IV/IV.

fig. 3 Édouard Manet (French, 1832–1883). M. Manet (The Artist’s Father) II, 1861. Etching, aquatint, and plate tone in black on ivory laid paper; 187 × 156 mm (image/plate); 357 × 267 mm (sheet). The Art Institute of Chicago, Clarence Buckingham Collection, 1984.1111. Harris 7 II/II; Guérin 10 II/II; Moreau-Nélaton 51 II/II.

fig. 4 Édouard Manet (French, 1832–1883). Printed by Auguste Delâtre (French, 1822–1907). The Spanish Singer, 1861/62. Etching, lavis, and roulette in black on ivory China paper; 298 × 242 mm (image); 298 × 244 mm (plate); 340 × 320 mm (sheet). The Art Institute of Chicago, J. W. Loewenthal Fund, 1921.282. Harris 12 V/VII; Guérin 16 V/V; Moreau-Nélaton 4 V/V.

fig. 5 Édouard Manet (French, 1832–1883). The Little Gypsies, 1861/62. Etching and drypoint in black on ivory laid paper; 197 × 139 mm (image/plate); 368 × 268 mm (sheet). The Art Institute of Chicago, William McCallin McKee Memorial Endowment, 1948.397. Harris 17; Guérin 20; Moreau-Nélaton 61.

fig. 6 Édouard Manet (French, 1832–1883). The Little Girl, 1861/62. Etching and drypoint with plate tone in brown on ivory laid paper; 207 × 119 mm (image/plate); 420 × 301 mm (sheet). The Art Institute of Chicago, William McCallin McKee Memorial Endowment, 1947.545. Harris 19 II/II; Guérin 25 II/II; Moreau-Nélaton 12 II/II.

fig. 7 Édouard Manet (French, 1832–1883) after Diego Rodriguez de Velázquez (Spanish, 1599–1660). Phillip IV King of Spain, 1862.
